newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - July 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - July 30.

text.p: Husband key to mystery -- police: Australian police said on Tuesday night that the person they thought could help them most as they tried to unravel the suspected murder of a New Zealand woman was her husband in Nelson. Page 1.

Firefighters want advance levy fund used: Fire chiefs were mad to slash firefighter numbers to cut costs while $60 million of taxpayer money languished in the fire service advance levy account, the Professional Firefighters Union said on Tuesday. Page 2.

Rata tributes flow in Parliament: The normal business of Parliament was interrupted for 45 minutes on Tuesday to pay respects to a Matiu Rata who Attorney-General Paul East said had not got the recognition he deserved during his life. Page 2.
'Let us play' plea from students: "Let us play" was a student's simple plea on Tuesday as the prospect of a ban from inter-school sport still hung over the Aranui High School Sports academy. Page 1.
MP rues lenient stance: Immigration Minister Max Bradford says he should have followed official advice instead of allowing a brain-damaged woman into New Zealand on compassionate grounds. Page 6.
Rally gains pace as bulls take charge: New Zealand shares thundered into bull mark territory on Tuesday -- several stocks traded at record highs. Page 30.

Southpower disputes follow deregulation: Contingent liabilities of more than $25 million faced by Southpower group are a result of the deregulation of the energy industry, says the chairman, John Gray. Page 29.
Consumer pays price of weaker NZ dollar: Dearer new and secondhand cars, costlier overseas holidays and price rises for other imported goods are the likely tradeoff for a sliding New Zealand dollar.

BellSouth condemns government inaction: BellSouth New Zealand on Tuesday lambasted government inaction on competition issues in the telecommunications market, lending its moral support to Clear Communications' High Court action filed against the Crown last week.
